text: and the inquiry has found that his
murder was an operation of the Russian
security service the FSB and the inquiry
goes on to say the killing was probably
approved by President Putin as well as
the then director of the FSB
and this is actually the report and
which we've been looking at over the
past hour and a half and of course it's
taken 10 years to get to this very very
important point Alexander Litvinenko of
course was killed in November 2006 and
only now do we have the results of an
inquiry and the absolutely key quote
from sera Berto in the retired judge who
chaired the inquiry is that he said
taking into account all the evidence and
analysis and what he means by that is
also the closed evidence ie from the
British intelligence services from mi6
presumably in which he says I find the
operation to kill Alexander Litvinenko
was probably approved by Nikolai
patrushev who was the head of Russia's
main intelligence agency the FSB at the
time and very close to Vladimir Putin
and by Vladimir Putin himself so this is
very very significant the fact that mr.
Putin has been named in this report is
probably approving the key word also
there is probably he cannot be sure
about it but he says probably what he is
sure about in his conclusions is that
mr. Litvinenko was poisoned in the Pine
bar of the Millennium Hotel in Mayfair
in central London in 2006 that he was
deliberately poisoned and it was carried
out by Andrey Lugovoy and Dmitry Kovtun
who for many years have been the two
chief suspects and of course we know
that Andrey Lugovoy had been in the FSB
as in the Intelligence Agency of the
Russians and had also been in the
federal protection service also within
the kind of intelligence apparatus and
had strong links with the FSB and he
goes on to say that the killing they the
poisoning in London was under the
action of the FSB the Intelligence
Agency
